I didn't even really care about this game [b] at all [/b] at it's initial release - and I was today's old in which the devs decided to put the game on sale and had me like:
  
[i] "Hmm, the Bioshock collection is on  a big sale, should I get it or nah?" [/i] 
  
I was even hesitant in buying it, but I swear if there were other versions of me from different universes who decided to pass on this wonderful clusterf*** of a game - [b] he's totally missing out on the best game-play and narrative experience he may ever get into. [/b] 
   
And I'm feeling sorry for those versions of me for not being able to experience it.
   
[i] 11/10 better than orgasms [/i]

Ottima storia e meccaniche intriganti, anche l'ambientazione soddisfa. Sicuramente un gioco invecchiato benissimo ed ancora in grado di sorprendere (e spesso in sconto, il che non fa mai male). Consigliato anche a chi non ha troppa dimestichezza con gli sparatutto, e non serve neanche aver giocato i primi 2 Bioshock per goderne pienamente|
Edit: ho appena finito il gioco e la trama si rivela MOZZAFIATO! Consiglio caldamente la lettura dell'articolo di IGN per comprenderla pienamente, merita in quanto Ã¨ stata veramente studiata a pennello e combacia magnificamente.

this is my first Bioshock game and man, this is up there. If you're into movies like Interstellar, Donnie Darko, or Predestination, this game has a story that fits that type of storytelling. Its weird to compare this game to those movies at first since the story kinda plays out like a traditional "save the princess from the castle with a dragon guarding her" type of tale, which to me is amazing but it gets more complex then that and its done well. The relationship between the main character you play (Booker) and the girl (Elizabeth) is expertly done and it ties with the gameplay. However, there is one recycled boss fight that gets annoying and the entire part of that lasts like an hour if your guns suck, but that's a minor complaint. The gameplay is fun, the world is gorgeous, and i'm definetly going to check out every other Bioshock game and DLC since everything together costed $15 for me lol.
This game is epic and burial at sea dlc is very good too

Lo recomiendo mucho, ahora a probar otro dia el contenido de los dlc. Si vuelven a ver la oferta no duden en comprarla uwu

Good game.  Great story.  Unless you're a racist, then you're going to hate it.  I played it back in the day and decided to try it on Steam.  More combat oriented and less exploring/adventure than I remember but still fun.  I didn't care much for the DLC's though.  Just seemed to be beating a dead horse story wise and nothing really new play wise.  Overall still a gem though.

The lore is beautifully written and fully encompasses "understanding through experience".
It requires a suspense of disbelief to get it going, then beautifully cycles across common themes to show (not tell) you how you belong in this quantum entanglement of worlds. 

(Spoilers!) Since there are multiple fan theories to string it together, I thought I'll put out my own interpretation of the Burial at Sea Ep 2 ending.  
Both Booker and Elizabeth were destined to a cycle of violence throughout their lives (constants) and their lasting effects would result in different endings across the multiverses (variables).
However, at the end of Burial at Sea Ep 2 - I understood it as (quantum?) plot disentanglement.
In all the other realities, they would end horribly despite being foreseen by an Omniscient Elizabeth.
While she could see being each door and how they end, she could not change the constants that mattered to her - ending the cycle of violence that plagues the DeWitts. 

When the Omniscient Elizabeth chose to follow the events of the BaS Ep2: she did so knowing that: 
1) she was going to die, though we all do eventually
2) it was the only one that mattered: the Omniscient Elizabeth would always exist in the other realities and thus would see to that their endings would cease the constant cycle of suffering.
3) she was going to be ok in ceasing the violence in this one without her Omniscience. 
(Her imagined) Booker showed her that while she had lost the ability to see the future in this reality, she had a cause that would propel her to fulfill her reason for coming back to Rapture. Omniscient Elizabeth probably realised that in this reality, there would be no need for Omniscience or the understanding of the future in this reality
4) this was the only reality worth dying for. And worth giving up her Omniscience for. Omniscient Elizabeth probably realised that her suffering will always be a constant in all the realities but this was the only reality that breaks the Circle of suffering and shows that Jack eventually saving the little sisters is proof of this. 

Overall, Burial at Sea EP 2 seems to be the linearisation of the quantum multiverses' multiple plotlines into a single plotline that, while no longer controlled by Omniscience Elizabeth - was able to finally move past the constant - the cycle of violence and suffering. 

Other reasons why you should love the game:
- the art is fecking amazing (though the models for the birds are weird)
This includes the music, emotional tidbits via voice character messages, artistic rendition of the imaginary universes and more. Design of characters, guns, enemies as well as gameplay are incredibly dynamic across the main game and the DLCs.

- the storyline is some inception-esque loop that makes them unforgettable. It encompasses the BS1 mechanic of having to remember important points in the story to fully appreciate and understand the universe you are thrown into

- in the game, you cycle through various themes that are relevant to real life: religion, racism, war, torture, science and politics. It definitely makes it all the more memorable imagining you were involved in these events and how despite surviving, it does not make any one feel like a survivor more than a victim. Shame that the games always have a really dark ending where death seems to be the best means of closure - it shows that there are things worth dying for.

Most importantly, no fecking bugs! Screw BS2 remastered, that crap won't continue without crashing every 15mins. FML

Absolutely amazing storytelling. I've been in awe for about an hour, but still the tremble after the ending is yet to stop. Oh my fking god, daamn good I am literally crying. AMAZING AF

Looking back, Bioshock Infinite feels like one last farewell from the golden age of linear single-player games, Nowadays making a linear single-player game with such density of content and assets seems unthinkable. Almost every developer has now got their eyes solely on either multiplayer or open-world games that are easier to monetize and capable of consuming more players' time.

My advice: buy it, treasure it, savor it, enjoy it while it lasts.

great game great story line. had 0 issues playing.
Epic game.  Slightly too easy combat but flows well.  The story is what makes it.  And of course...the ending is unexpected.
Ğ•ÑĞ»Ğ¸ Ñ‚Ñ‹ Ğ½Ğµ Ğ¿Ğ¾ÑˆĞµĞ» Ğ³ÑƒĞ³Ğ»Ğ¸Ñ‚ÑŒ ĞºĞ¾Ğ½Ñ†Ğ¾Ğ²ĞºÑƒ ÑÑ‚Ğ¾Ğ¹ Ğ¸Ğ³Ñ€Ñ‹,Ğ¿Ğ¾Ğ·Ğ´Ñ€Ğ°Ğ²Ğ»ÑÑ,Ñ‚Ñ‹-Ğ³ĞµĞ½Ğ¸Ğ¹

An incredibly amazing experience, from start to finish.  It's a beautiful, whimsical, twisted, dark, comedic, magical, heartbreaking, action thriller. I have never played anything like it before. But it's not without its flaws...

The game play/combat system isn't the best I've experienced in a FPS.  However, for the base game itself (not including the DLCs) it is serviceable as the devs made sure to pace  the action accordingly to your limitations and special abilities.  

Field of view and mouse sensitivity settings can be an issue for some, even with the in game options to adjust them, but the good news is, you can fine tune both to your liking via the config file, so all is forgiven here. :)

Bioshock Infinite is without exaggeration, a fantastic game. Definitely recommend it, at  least for the compelling story.  It left an impression on me for days after I finished the campaign.

I urge you to play this in 4k resolution with maxed out settings if your machine can handle it at 60fps or higher. It's like playing a beautiful (but twisted) smoothly animated CG movie. Once you're introduced to Elizabeth, the game really begins to shine. Upon completing the game, I was left in awe with a small knot in my throat.
I've never been this immersed in a game before. 8/10
